profiles:
Summary Hewins Financial Advisors, LLC is an SEC-registered, wealth management and advisory firm. Founded in 1999, Hewins (which also does business under the names Wipfli Hewins Investment Advisors, LLC, DZH Phillips Wealth Management, and Cue Wealth Management Solutions) is headquartered in the San Francisco Bay Area. We have offices in California, Florida, Illinois, Minnesota, Missouri, Oregon, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, and are proud affiliates of Wipfli LLP, a large regional CPA firm.  
 
We provide our clients with experienced financial planning, a disciplined investment management approach, as well as the time and resources needed to formulate a prudent investment strategy. We also offer financial planning services with the aid of enhanced software that performs interactive financial planning, which enables our clients to explore their financial futures in real time with visual images to further illustrate the consequences of various choices. Our relationship as a member of the Callan Independent Adviser Group (IAG) and being an approved Dimensional Fund Advisor (DFA) extends our access to in-depth, high-quality research and information resources. We are committed to serving our clients in a manner consistent with our fiduciary responsibilities, aiming to make their complex financial lives a little easier.  
 
Specialties include financial planning and comprehensive wealth management services for individuals and families and use of an interactive planning tool featuring real-time scenarios. Experience Associate Consultant Hewins Financial | Wipfli Hewins February 2015  – Present (7 months) San Francisco Bay Area Associate Director of Financial Aid Stanford University, Graduate School of Business January 2010  –  May 2012  (2 years 5 months) Stanford, Ca Manage the processing and distribution of over $20 million in student loans to over 500 graduate business students. 
Counsel students on budgeting issues, financial obligations to the University and their lenders as well as advising students on credit denials. 
Supervise the daily tasks of the office to ensure students are responded to within 24-48 hours. 
Organize and manage financial aid events to assist in financial education to over 1000 students.  
Represent the Graduate School of Business Financial Aid Office in the Director's absence. Assistant Director of Financial Aid Stanford University, Graduate School of Business July 2006  –  December 2009  (3 years 6 months) Stanford, Ca Effectively communicated the loan products and services lenders offered to the student population. 
Assisted in the hiring, supervision and training of the Financial Aid Advisors. 
Managed the preparation of useful and timely federal and institutional reports and reconciliation. 
Performed in-depth financial aid need analysis under rigid funding and timing constraints while maintaining an audit trail. Financial Aid Advisor Stanford University, Graduate School of Business April 2003  –  June 2006  (3 years 3 months) Stanford, Ca Administered and enhanced a $50,000 budget loan forgiveness program to assist MBA graduates in the repayment of student loans.  
Spearheaded the preparation of financial aid documentation for yearly audit. 
Identified a major error in our lender repayment management system, saving our students thousands of dollars in student loan interest. Cost Account Assistant PACIFIC SCIENTIFIC ENERGETIC MATERIALS March 2001  –  January 2003  (1 year 11 months) San Carlos, Ca Client relations. Assessed the needs of customers and created databases that would allow for better accountability of their products. 
Responsible for numerous contracts in programs valued at a half a million dollars with customers from large businesses.; Improved and managed month end cost reports that budgeted over $8 million dollars for customer, Lockheed Martin. 
Generated and provided monthly budget forecasts that supported cost effective proposals to the customer. 
Managed a database that maintained organization among 15 customer contracts and proposals. Experience Financial Aid Advisor Stanford University Graduate School of Business January 2014  – Present (1 year 8 months) Associate Director of Financial Aid Five Branches University September 2012  –  January 2014  (1 year 5 months) San Jose, CA -Development, administration, and interpretation of financial aid policies and procedures in accordance with established federal, state and institutional guidelines and ensure compliance with all programs. 
-Communicate accurate and comprehensive information regarding the availability of financial aid programs, loan procedures and obligations, and budget information via phone, personal contact, email and other forms of written communication. 
-Perform thorough application verification and awarding per federal, state, institutional and campus-based guidelines. 
-Report loan origination and disbursements to Common Origination Disbursement (COD) and perform monthly reconciliation that incorporates the Office of Financial Aid and Accounting. 
-Research and update all institutional financial aid documents and conduct in-person entrance and exit counseling. - Managed the earnings of over 500 Student Assistants in the FWS program, decreasing overages in earnings. 
- Developed and maintained solid relationships with Supervisors across campus 
- Researched all necessary paperwork to create effective and informative financial aid publications  
- Created template for FWS Online Job Board 
- Advised students and parents regarding financial aid procedures and policies while maintaining confidentiality 
- Handled general office management, including mail, daily record maintenance, coordinated important office projects and supervised Student Assistants. Summary Within the financial aid industry, Daniel has presented all over the country on issues related to equity, inclusion, and access to education. In his spare time he has written a piece of historical fiction set to come out in April. A synopsis is below. 
 
In 1850, Tomás travels from the Philippines to strike it rich in the California gold rush and win respect as a subconscious way to overcome racial barriers. In his struggle to gain legitimacy he progresses through various stages of racial identity development. He is not alone in this regard. John, an American, has remained in California after the Mexican War to police the camps. Cath has arrived from Ireland to escape her own experience with oppression. Jungdo has come from China to avoid the pain of his past brought on by his own cultural hegemony. All fight for legitimacy in an effort to continue their own way of life, at the risk of not living at all.
